territory.notes: The precise names and tenures of these pre-colonial states are sometimes difficult to discern from the sources consulted, but in general, they correspond to the three major ethnic groups of pre-colonial (and present-day) Namibia: The Nama, Herero, and Ovambo (or Ambo). Ovamboland was a term used by Europeans in the 19th century to refer to the northern part of present-day Namibia under the political control of the Ovambo/Ambo (a conglomeration of eight Bantu-speaking societies/chieftanships). Ovamboland remained under the practical control of Ovambo leadership longer than Hereroland or the Red Nation. Germany did not solidify its claims to Ovamboland until 1890, and Ovamboland retained its practical sovereignty throughout much of the existence of German South West Africa and even the early years of South West Africa. Ovamboland’s Kwanyama King/Chief Mandume actively fought to maintain Ovamboland’s independence from 1914 until his death at the hands of South African troops in 1917.
